questions.text: The following muscle is marked in the anatomy practical exam, the examiner asks you to provide the origin, insertion, and nerve supply of it. What would your answer be?

choices.text: Origin:  Radius, Insertion: Ulna, Nerve supply: Median nerve
Origin:  Radius, Insertion: Ulna, Nerve supply: Radial nerve
Origin: Ulna, Insertion: Radius, Nerve supply: Median nerve
Origin: Ulna, Insertion: Radius, Nerve supply: Radial nerve

questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image is the pronator quadratus muscle. The answer is origin: Ulna, insertion: Radius, nerve supply: Median nerve. 

The pronator quadratus is a flat quadrilateral-shaped muscle, that extends across the front of the distal ends of the radius and ulna. It arises from the anterior surface of the shaft of the ulna and inserts into the shaft of the radius and the ulnar notch of the radius.

The pronator quadratus is innervated by the median nerve (C7 and 8). It is supplied by the anterior interosseus artery. It causes the pronation of the forearm at the radioulnar joint.

questions.text: Reticular fibres are not present in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Reticular fibres are not present in the thymus.

Reticular fibres are fine, anastomosing fibres composed of mainly type III collagen. They differ from type I collagen fibres in that, they are finer and are arranged in the form of a network (reticulum). The fibres appear black in colour on staining with silver impregnation. Due to this affinity to silver salts, they are also known as argentophil fibres.

Reticular fibres are mainly found in:

  • All lymphoid organs like spleen, lymph node, and bone marrow (except thymus).
  • Glands, liver and kidneys.
  • The basement membrane of all epithelia.
  • Smooth muscle and nerve cells.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis now presents with weakness and loss of the bulk of thenar muscles and was diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome. Which of the following structure is spared in this condition?
questions.solution:
Radial nerve is spared in carpal tunnel syndrome as it is not a content of carpal tunnel. 

10 structures pass through the carpal tunnel, most of which are flexor tendons (not the muscles themselves).

Carpal tunnel contents (10 structures): Also can be taken as 4 structures only if FDP and FDS are counted as 2 structures. 

  • Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP-4 tendons).
  • Flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS-4 tendons).
  • Flexor pollicis longus (FPL-1 tendon).
  • Median nerve between tendons of FDP and FDS.

Carpal tunnel syndrome occurs due to the entrapment or compression of the median nerve as it traverses underneath the carpal tunnel to enter into the wrist. Patients usually present with pain associated with tingling and numbness involving the thumb, index and middle fingers, and radial half of the ring finger. The little finger is usually spared as it is innervated by the ulnar nerve. Tinel's sign and Phalen's test are seen on examining patients with carpal tunnel syndrome. A late sign of carpal tunnel syndrome is thenar atrophy as seen in this patient. 

Some conditions associated with carpal tunnel syndrome include the third trimester of pregnancy, people with repetitive trauma, rheumatoid arthritis, and cysts from the carpal joints. 

Management involves measures to remove any repetitive insults that cause symptoms, wrist splinting, nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, steroid injection, etc. Surgical decompression is usually indicated in patients that do not improve.

Note: Ulnar nerve passes superficial to carpal tunnel

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was brought to the hospital following RTA.  Chest X-ray reveals fracture as shown by the arrow. The long bone fractured in the X-Ray is of which of the following types?
questions.solution:
Given X-Ray shows the fracture of clavicle. Clavicle is a modified long bone, as it has a modified shaft and no medullary cavity.

Long bones are classified as follows:

  • Typical long bones (see figure) have an elongated shaft (diaphysis) and two expanded ends (epiphysis). The shaft has a central medullary cavity and a nutrient foramen directed away from the growing end. E.g., humerus, ulna, radius, femur, tibia, and fibula.
  • Miniature long bones contain only one epiphysis. E.g., metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges.
  • Modified long bones have a modified shaft or ends, and no medullary cavity. E.g., clavicle.

questions.text: Which of the following dural venous sinuses receives the great cerebral vein of Galen as its tributary?
questions.solution:
The venous sinus marked with 'B' in the given image is the straight sinus. The great cerebral vein of Galen drains into the straight sinus.

The straight sinus is a continuation of the inferior sagittal sinus. It lies in the junction of the falx cerebri with tentorium cerebelli. The straight sinus further drains into one of the transverse sinuses (mostly the left).

Other options

A - Superior sagittal sinus

C - Superior petrosal sinus

D - Sigmoid sinus

questions.text: All of the following form the marked structure except:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the dorsal digital expansion of the middle finger. Palmar interossei do not attach to the middle finger and therefore it does not contribute to the dorsal digital expansion of the middle finger. 

Palmar interossei are unipennate muscles originating from their own metacarpal bone. Their function is adduction. The middle finger does not need adduction and hence does not have palmar interossei.

Dorsal interossei are bipennate muscles originating from the adjacent metacarpal bone. They attach to the middle three fingers on both sides and do not attach on the thumb and little finger. Their function is abduction. The thumb and little finger have other muscles for abduction.

The lateral 2 lumbricals are unipennate and medial 2 lumbricals are bipennate. Their function is flexion at metacarpophalangeal joints.

questions.text: A young man presents to the physician with a history of erosions on the scalp, face, and chest for the past 6 months. He says that initially, the lesions were like fluid-filled blisters, which later ruptured to form erosions. On examination, multiple lesions are seen over the scalp, face, chest, and also oral cavity. Nikolsky's sign is positive. This disease is caused due to a defect in which of the following layers?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of flaccid blisters over the skin and mucosa in a young man, along with a positive Nikolsy sign, are suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. It mainly affects the epidermis, which is marked as 1 in the above slide.

Pemphigus vulgaris is caused by the autoantibodies that are directed mainly against desmoglein 3. This is present in the epidermis. Other intraepidermal immunobullous disorders are pemphigus foliaceous, endemic pemphigus, and paraneoplastic pemphigus.

Examples of subepidermal immunobullous disorders are bullous pemphigoid, linear IgA disease, pemphigoid gestationis, epidermolysis bullosa acquisita, etc.

Structure of skin:

The epidermis is the outermost layer of skin and is made up of five layers, or strata, of different cell types. It is made of stratified squamous keratinised epithelium and consists of the following layers. 

  • Stratum basale - It is the deepest layer of the epidermis and is made of a single layer of columnar cells. It contains keratinocytes and is also called stratum germinativum. 
  • Stratum spinosum - Contains several layers of polygonal keratinocytes. These cells are connected with the help of desmosomes. This is also called the prickle cell layer.
  • Stratum granulosum - These are made up of flattened cells that have deeply staining granules in their cytoplasm. The granules contain keratohyalin.
  • Stratum lucidum - It lies superficial to the stratum granulosum. The cell boundaries are indistinct, and this layer appears homogenous.
  • Stratum corneum - It is the most superficial layer of the epidermis. This layer is acellular. It is made up of flattened scale-like elements (squames) containing keratin filaments within a protein. The squames are held together by a glue-like material that contains lipids and carbohydrates.

The dermis is divided into two layers:

  • The papillary dermis is the superficial layer of the dermis and contains dense connective tissue of dermal papillae. The papillae are best developed in the thick skin of the palms and soles. Each papilla contains a capillary loop.
  • The reticular layer is the deeper layer of the dermis and consists of thick bundles of collagen fibres. It also has some elastic fibres. 

The dermis rests on subcutaneous tissue. The subcutaneous layer is called panniculus adiposus. It is responsible for giving a smooth contour to the skin. It is absent in the superficial fascia of the eyelids, the scrotum and the penis. 

The below image shows lesions of pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: A patient with mild hip and back pain is asked to perform some movements at the hip joints to look for any pathology. The following movement done by him at the right hip joint is facilitated by all the given muscles, except _______.
questions.solution:
The image shows extension movement being done at the right hip joint. The iliacus is not involved in the extension of the hip. It causes flexion of the hip joint.

Muscles involved in extension of the hip joint are:

  • Gluteus maximus
  • Biceps femoris
  • Adductor magnus
  • Semitendinosus
  • Semimembranosus

Muscles involved in flexion of the hip joint are:

  • Psoas major
  • Iliacus
  • Rectus femoris

questions.text: A patient presents with a high-grade fever with spikes, headache, and double vision. There is no loss of vision. On examination, he had bilateral periorbital edema and proptosis. Further examinations reveal paralysis of extraocular muscles, loss of pupillary reflex, and loss of corneal reflex. However, the visual acuity is preserved. What is the most likely site of location of the structure that is involved in the disease?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, the patient has paralysis of extraocular muscles, loss of pupillary reflex, and loss of corneal reflex. There is no loss of vision. This means that there is paralysis of the oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve, abducens nerve, and ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. The optic nerve is spared. The most likely site of involvement is the cavernous sinus which is marked as B. 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is usually caused due to an infection. The source of infection can be from facial veins, sinuses, middle ear, pharynx, or tonsils. This will lead to impaired drainage of the blood from the eye and inflammation of the nerves present in the sinus leading to ophthalmoplegia. 

The patients present with high-grade fever with spikes. This is called picket fence fever. They might also have periorbital edema, eyelid erythema, chemosis, ptosis, and proptosis that occurs due to impaired drainage of the orbit.

Multiple cranial nerves are related to this sinus. They are:

  • Oculomotor nerve- It supplies superior, inferior, and medial recti muscles, and inferior oblique. It also supplies parasympathetic fibers to the ciliary ganglion. Therefore paralysis of this nerve leads to paralysis of extraocular muscles with loss of pupillary reflex.
  • Trochlear nerve- Damage to this nerve leads to superior oblique paralysis.
  • Ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve- It supplies, cornea, ciliary body, iris, lacrimal gland conjunctiva, etc. Damage to this nerve will lead to loss of corneal reflex
  • Abducens nerve-Damage to this nerve leads to lateral rectus palsy.

 Cavernous sinus

The cavernous sinuses are two large venous plexuses that lie on either side of the body of the sphenoid bone, extending from the superior orbital fissure to the apex of the petrous temporal bone.

Structures related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinuses are

  • Oculomotor nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • The ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve

Within the cavernous sinus are the 

  • Abducens nerve
  • Cavernous part of the internal carotid artery

The structure marked as A is the orbital apex. In orbital apex syndrome structures passing through superior orbital fissure and optic canal are affected. Therefore disease affecting this area will have a combination of multiple cranial nerve palsy and visual loss.

The structure marked as C is foramen rotundum. It transmits the maxillary nerve. Injury at this area will lead to loss of sensation over the cheek and philtrum.

The structure marked as D is the foramen ovale. It transmits the mandibular nerve, accessory meningeal artery, and the lesser petrosal nerve.

questions.text:
The following nerve is marked in an anatomy exam, the attached question asks for its branches. You would answer ____.
  1. Long ciliary nerves
  2. Supratrochlear nerve
  3. Infratrochlear nerve
  4. Supraorbital nerve
  5. Infraorbital nerve
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the frontal nerve and it is the largest branch of the ophthalmic nerve. Its branches are supraorbital and supratrochlear nerves.

It can be identified as it passes forwards towards the rim of the orbit on the levator palpebrae superioris muscle.

Frontal nerve: It enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure. It passes forwards towards the rim of the orbit on levator palpebrae superioris; about halfway along this course, it divides into the supraorbital and supratrochlear nerves.

Supra-orbital nerve: It continues forwards along the levator palpebrae superioris until it leaves the orbit through the supraorbital notch or foramen. It emerges onto the forehead and supplies the mucous membrane that lines the frontal sinus, the conjunctiva and skin covering the upper eyelid, and the skin over the forehead and scalp.

Supratrochlear nerve: It runs medially above the trochlea for the tendon of the superior oblique. It gives a descending branch to the infra-trochlear nerve and ascends to the forehead through the frontal notch to supply the conjunctiva and skin covering the upper eyelid and the forehead.

Other options:

Long ciliary nerves and infratrochlear nerve are branches of the nasociliary nerve.

The infraorbital nerve is a branch of the maxillary nerve.

questions.text: In an anatomy practical exam, a student was shown the anterior surface of the spinal cord as shown below and was asked to identify the marked structure. The structure marked as '?' is a modification of:
questions.solution:
The structure marked as "?" in the above image is ligamentum denticulatum. It is a modification of the pia mater.

The ligamentum denticulatum(Dentate ligament) is a flat, fibrous sheet on either side of the spinal cord between the ventral and dorsal spinal nerve roots. Its medial border is continuous with the subpial connective tissue and the lateral border forms a series of 21 triangular processes on each side connecting it to the dura mater giving it a serrated appearance. The lowest projection of ligamentum denticulatum lies at the level of T12 and L1 spinal nerves.

The first projection crosses behind the vertebral artery where it is attached to the dura mater and is separated by the artery from the first cervical ventral root. Its site of attachment to the dura mater is above the rim of the foramen magnum.

questions.text: Which nerve passes through the foramen marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is mandibular foramen and inferior alveolar nerve passes through it.

The inferior alveolar nerve (IAN), a branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3), it descends behind the lateral pterygoid, at the lower border of the muscle, the nerve passes between the sphenomandibular ligament and the mandibular ramus and enters the mandibular canal via the mandibular foramen

The mandibular foramen is located above the mandibular angle, the opening through which the IAN and the vessels of the mandible pass.
The IAN continues its course through the mandibular canal and then branches off to supply the lower teeth, gums, and lower lip.

questions.text: During a thyroidectomy, the surgeon accidentally damages the nerve marked in the image below. Which of the following is true about the postoperative course in this patient?

choices.text: Initial hoarseness in voice which may improve with time

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis will lead to initial hoarseness of voice, which may improve with time.

Recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis can be unilateral or bilateral. Unilateral palsy is more common on the left side because of the long course of the nerve. They are more commonly injured during thyroid surgeries, neck trauma, thyroid disease, and bronchogenic carcinoma.

The recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all the muscles of the larynx except for the cricothyroid. Therefore, in unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, these muscles are paralysed. The affected vocal cord lies in the paramedian position (option B).

Postoperatively, the injury can go unnoticed, or the patient may complain of mild hoarseness in the voice. This hoarseness is because the paralysed muscle cannot close the glottis during phonation.

Hoarseness might improve over time because the unaffected muscle compensates and closes the glottis by hyperadduction of the cord. The patient will not have difficulty in breathing or stridor (option C).

Generally, no treatment is required (option A). Laryngoplasty type I is needed if there is no compensation from the normal muscle.

In bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, both the vocal cords are paralysed and assume the paramedian position. Because the vocal cords are close to the midline, the phonation can be normal. However, since these vocal cords cannot abduct, the patients will have stridor and breathing difficulty. This condition requires an emergency tracheostomy to maintain the patient's airway.

The image given below shows the nerves of the neck.

questions.text: A 16-year-old gymnast was brought to the emergency department after suffering severe trauma during the performance. She presented with painful hip instability. MRI revealed ligament tear which is caused by hyperextension of the hip joint. Which of the following​ ligaments is likely to be torn?
questions.solution:
The iliofemoral ligament resists the hyperextension of hip joint and hence, is likely to be injured.

Iliofemoral ligament or ligament of Bigelow is the strongest ligament of the hip joint. It is an inverted-Y-shaped ligament. The apex is attached between the anterior inferior iliac spine and acetabular margin. The base is attached to the intertrochanteric line. This ligament prevents the hyperextension of the hip joint.

The image given below shows the iliofemoral ligament.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought to the clinic with complaints of intermittent gross hematuria for the past 2 days. The boy had pain in the left flank region along with left testicular pain. Which of the following marked structure is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of nutcracker syndrome, in which the left renal vein is affected. In the above image, the structure marked as 'c' is the left renal vein as it lies anterior to the aorta and posteroinferior to the superior mesenteric artery.

Nutcracker syndrome: The compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery appears in the sagittal plane as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein). This condition is also called left renal vein entrapment syndrome.

Clinical presentation:

  • The most common clinical manifestation is intermittent macroscopic haematuria. Repeated episodes of gross haematuria and left flank pain are present.
  • Since the left gonadal vein drains via the left renal vein it may also result in left testicular pain in men or left lower quadrant pain in women.
  • Nausea and vomiting can result due to compression of the splanchnic veins.
  • In some cases, it is characterized by left renal vein hypertension secondary to compression and has been associated with haematuria and varicocele in children.

questions.text: The structure not passing through the aortic opening of the diaphragm is:
questions.solution:
The vagal trunk does not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

It passes through the esophageal opening at the level of T10 vertebra.

questions.text: An elderly man complains of inability to extend the fingers of his left hand. On examination, the patient was able to extend his elbow and wrist, but cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joints of the hand. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of radial nerve injury. The structure marked as 4 is the radial nerve. It can be seen dividing into the posterior interosseous nerve and the superficial radial nerve in the elbow.

The radial nerve originates from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. It mainly supplies the extensors of the elbow, wrist, and fingers. Branches of the radial nerve:

  • In the axilla and the radial groove- It supplies the triceps muscles.
  • Proximal to the lateral epicondyle- nerve to brachioradialis, extensor carpi radialis longus

At the tip of the lateral epicondyle, the nerve divides into the superficial radial nerve and posterior interosseous nerve. The posterior interosseus nerve supplies the supinator, extensor digitorum, extensor digiti minimi, extensor carpi ulnaris, extensor pollicis longus, extensor indicis, abductor pollicis longus, and extensor pollicis brevis. 

The superficial branch of the radial nerve supplies the skin over the anatomical snuffbox, lateral half of the dorsum of hand, and lateral 2 1⁄2 digits till their distal interphalangeal joints

Radial nerve injuries:

  • Very high lesions like the lesions around the shoulder joint and axilla, it results in loss of extension of the elbow, wrist, and hand.
  • In high lesions like fractures of the humerus and prolonged tourniquet pressure, there is wrist drop, due to weakness of the radial extensors of the wrist, as well as inability to extend the metacarpophalangeal joints. It will also have a sensory loss on the skin over the anatomical snuff box.
  • Low lesions occur due to the fracture or dislocations of the elbow. The wrist and elbow extension is preserved but the patient cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joint.

questions.text: Decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs at which level?
questions.solution:
The decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs in the midbrain, at the level of the inferior colliculus.

The midbrain has four decussations:

  • At the level of the superior colliculus:
    • Ventral tegmental decussation of the rubrospinal tract
    • Dorsal tegmental decussation of the tectospinal tract
  • At the level of the inferior colliculus:
    • Decussation of superior cerebellar peduncles
    • Decussation of trochlear nerve

questions.text: A man suffered from a stab injury to his hand and the muscle marked in the image below is injured. Which of the following movements will be affected in him?
questions.solution:
The muscle injured is the abductor pollicis brevis. Injury to this muscle will lead to loss of abduction of the thumb. Abduction of the thumb refers to the drawing of the thumb ventrally in a plane that is at the right angle to the palm of the hand.

The abductor pollicis brevis is a thin subcutaneous muscle that is a part of the thenar eminence. It arises from the flexor retinaculum, tubercles of the scaphoid, and trapezium bone. Its medial fibers are attached to the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, and its lateral fibres join the dorsal digital expansion of the thumb.

It helps in the abduction of the thumb. 

Other muscles of the thenar eminence

Medial to abductor pollicis brevis muscle is the flexor pollicis brevis. It flexes the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb.

Adductor pollicis arises by oblique and transverse heads. The oblique head attaches to the capitate bone, bases of the second and third metacarpal bones, palmar ligament, and tendon of flexor carpi radialis. However, the majority of the fibers unite to form a tendon which is attached to the ulnar side of the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. It helps in the adduction of the thumb. Adduction is the approximation of the thumb to the palm of the hand.

Opponens pollicis muscle lies deep to the abductor pollicis brevis. It is attached to the lateral half of the palmar surface of the metacarpal bone of the thumb. It flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.

All the thenar muscles are supplied by the median nerve with the exception of the deep head of flexor pollicis brevis and adductor pollicis which are supplied by ulnar nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following structures marked in the given image of the sole of the foot, is involved in the Windlass mechanism?
questions.solution:
Plantar aponeurosis (marked 'A') is involved in the Windlass mechanism.

Windlass mechanism:

Dorsiflexion of the great toe causes heightening of the medial longitudinal arch of the foot. This is called the Windlass mechanism.

The anterior pillar of the medial longitudinal arch is formed by the medial three metatarsals and the posterior pillar is formed by the posterior part of the inferior calcaneal surface. Plantar aponeurosis acts as a tie beam and connects these pillars. Whenever the great toe is stretched, the plantar aponeurosis is also stretched, drawing the anterior and posterior pillars together. This results in the heightening of the arch.

Below image shows Windlass mechanism

Median longitudinal arch:

The arch between the heel proximally and the medial three metatarsophalangeal joints.

Bones involved: Calcaneus, talar head, navicular, the three cuneiforms and the medial three metatarsals.

Stability of arch:

  • Plantar aponeurosis (most important)
  • Spring ligament
  • Talocalcaneal ligaments
  • Deltoid ligament
  • Muscles: Flexor hallucis longus, Flexor digitorum longus, abductor hallucis, flexor digitorum brevis, Tibialis posterior and anterior
  • Bones

Related Pearl: Comparative features of the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot.

questions.text: Ligation of common hepatic artery will impair blood supply in:

choices.text: Right  gastric and right gastroepiploic artery
Right gastric and left gastric artery
Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels
Right gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.solution:
Ligation of the common hepatic artery will cause impairment in the blood supply through its branches i.e right gastric artery and right gastroepiploic artery.

Blood supply of the stomach:

The arterial supply of the stomach is contributed exclusively by the branches of the celiac trunk. They are:

  • Left gastric artery - Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
  • Splenic artery- This further divides into:
    • Short gastric arteries- Supplies the fundus of the stomach
    • Left gastroepiploic artery- Supplies the greater curvature of the stomach
  • Common hepatic artery, which gives the following branches
    • Right gastric artery- Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
    • Gastroduodenal artery- Right gastroepiploic artery arises from this and supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.

questions.text: Identify the type of gland depicted in the following image.
questions.solution:
The image shows an apocrine gland. There is shedding of the apical portion of the cell during the secretion.

Types of glands:

Apocrine Holocrine Eccrine(Merocrine)
Apical part of cell sheds off during discharge Whole-cell disintegrates during discharge The cell is intact and secretions are thrown out by exocytosis
Eg: Apocrine sweat glands in axilla and groin, mammary glands, the external auditory canal (ceruminous glands) and eyelids (glands of Moll)

Eg: Glands of Zeis and Meibomian gland 

Montgomery tubercle: Nipple and areola

Tyson's gland: External fold of the prepuce

Fordyce' spot: Vermillion border of lips and mucosa

Eg: Sweat glands on palms and soles

Found everywhere except clitoris, glans penis, labia minora, external auditory canal and lips

 

Notice that for the sweat glands, the duct mostly goes to the skin surface v/s Sebaceous gland which mostly opens to the hair follicle.

questions.text: A young female patient from a rural area presented with severe pain in the lower abdomen and pelvic regions and vaginal bleeding. Her last menstrual period was 2 months back. Her urine pregnancy test appeared positive. Her physician suspected a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. However, no medical imaging or laboratory procedure was available.  The physician could confirm the diagnosis by obtaining the blood from?
questions.solution:
The physician could confirm the diagnosis by obtaining the blood from the rectouterine pouch, which is also called the pouch of Douglas. This procedure is called culdocentesis.

The classic triad of symptoms in tubal pregnancy are

  • Severe lower abdominal pain
  • Amenorrhea- usually for 6-8 weeks before the appearance of the symptoms
  • Vaginal bleeding

If a ruptured ectopic pregnancy is suspected, then blood samples should be sent for haemoglobin estimation and blood grouping. Estimation of β-HCG can be used to confirm pregnancy. Once it is suspected, transvaginal sonography or laparoscopy can be performed to visualise the ruptured ectopic.

However, if the imaging techniques are not available, then culdocentesis can be performed. An 18 gauge lumbar puncture needle with a syringe is inserted into the rectouterine pouch by puncturing the posterior fornix. If non-clotting blood is obtained from the pouch, which has a hematocrit of more than 15%, it indicates the presence of ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

Peritoneum of the female pelvis:

In females, the peritoneum covers the anterior and anterolateral surface of the rectum, uterus, and urinary bladder. Spaces found in the female pelvis are:

  • Pararectal fossae- Present on either side of the rectum. They are limited laterally by the peritoneum that covers the uterosacral ligaments. 
  • Paravesical fossae- Present on either side of the bladder. It is limited laterally by the peritoneum, which covers the round ligament of the uterus.
  • Rectouterine pouch (pouch of Douglas)- The peritoneum, which covers the anterior surface of the rectum, is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterior surface of the posterior fornix of the vagina and the uterus, forming a rectouterine pouch.
  • Vesicouterine pouch- The peritoneum covering the fundus and body of the uterus is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterosuperior surface of the bladder, forming a vesicouterine pouch.
  • Ovarian fossa- a shallow depression in the peritoneal lining of the lateral pelvic wall between the peritoneal ridges. It is formed by the obliterated umbilical arteries anteriorly, the ureter posteriorly, and the external iliac vessels above. It lies behind the lateral attachment of the broad ligament and contains the ovary in nulliparous females.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve nucleus lies under the elevation of the marked area?
questions.solution:
The elevation marked in the image, in the lowermost area of the rhomboid fossa away from the striae medullaris is known as the vagal trigone. The vagal nucleus is present beneath the vagal trigone.

The given image represents the floor of the fourth ventricle. It is a shallow diamond-shaped or rhomboid-shaped depression on the dorsal surfaces of the pons and the rostral half of the medulla. It contains the nuclei of the cranial nerves V to XII. The fourth ventricle is continuous with the cerebral aqueduct cranially and the central canal of the spinal cord caudally.

The fourth ventricular floor is divided into superior and inferior halves by the striae medullaris. The superior triangular half is limited laterally by the superior cerebellar peduncles. The inferior triangular half is limited caudally by the gracile and cuneate tubercles that form the dorsal column. The floor is divided vertically into two halves by a longitudinal sulcus called the median sulcus. Each vertical half is further divided by the sulcus limitans to form the medial eminence and the lateral vestibular area.

Structures on the floor of the 4th ventricle (rhomboid fossa)

Ridges:

  • Transverse fibers: Striae medullaris divide the floor into superior and inferior halves.

Medial to lateral in upper triangular part:

  • Bilateral eminences: Medial eminence contain the facial colliculus coiled around the abducens nucleus.
  • Bilateral longitudinal sulcus: Sulcus limitans
  • Bilateral areas: Vestibular area contains the vestibular nucleus

Sulcus limitans forms:

  • The bluish-colored area at the uppermost end of sulcus limitans denotes the underlying locus coeruleus
  • Superior fovea: A small depression between the facial colliculus and the vestibular area
  • Inferior fovea: lateral limit of sulcus limitans

Lower triangular part:

  • Hypoglossal trigone: represents the medial eminence in the lower triangle. It consists of the hypoglossal nucleus.
  • Vagal trigone: Is present caudal to the hypoglossal triangle consisting of the dorsal nucleus of the vagus nerve
  • Funiculus separans: A narrow translucent ridge that is present caudal to the vagal trigone. It is separated from the gracile tubercle by the small area postrema separating it from the vagal trigone.

The roof of the fourth ventricle is formed by the superior and inferior medullary veli.

questions.text:
The type of cartilage shown in the image is found in:
  1. Thyroid cartilage
  2. Cricoid cartilage
  3. Corniculate cartilage
  4. Cuneiform cartilage
  5. Apices of arytenoids
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 3, 4 and 5 only. The above image shows elastic cartilage. It is seen in corniculate cartilage, cuneiform cartilage and apices of arytenoids. The given section is stained by Verhoeff’s method in which elastic fibres are stained bluish-black.

The elastic cartilage, like the hyaline cartilage, contains individual or small groups of chondrocytes that are surrounded by type II collagen fibrils. However, it differs from hyaline cartilage in that, much of the interterritorial matrix consists of fine yellow elastic fibres containing elastin protein and the surface of elastic cartilage is covered by perichondrium. On microscopy, elastic cartilage consists of:

  • Chondrocytes within lacunae
  • Elastic fibres in the matrix
  • Perichondrium with outer fibrous layer and the inner cellular layer

Elastic cartilage is found in:

  • External ear
  • External auditory meatus
  • Auditory tube
  • Corniculate cartilage
  • Cuneiform cartilage
  • Epiglottis
  • Apices of arytenoids

Thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage are composed of hyaline cartilage.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who is a known case of hypertension and diabetes mellitus,  presented with a palpable mass in the suprasternal space of burns. Which of the following is not a content of this space.
questions.solution:
External jugular vein is not present in Burns space. It is a content of supraclavicular space

Contents of the suprasternal space of Burns include:

  • Jugular venous arch formed by anterior jugular veins
  • Sternal head of right and left Sternocleidomastoid
  • Lymph nodes and interclavicular ligament

questions.text: A first-year medical student during a practical exam chooses a histological slide of the umbilical cord for discussion. The examiner focuses the slide as shown in the below image. The structure shown by the tip of the arrow develops from which of the following mesoderm?
questions.solution:
The structure shown by the tip of the arrow is Wharton’s jelly, which develops from extraembryonic mesoderm.

The extraembryonic mesoderm of the connecting stalk develops into a gelatinous substance known as Wharton’s jelly.  

When the tail fold of the embryo is formed, the connecting stalk moves towards the ventral aspect of the embryo. The connecting stalk is now attached only in the region of the umbilical opening. The extraembryonic mesoderm of the connecting stalk becomes Wharton's jelly in the umbilical cord. Wharton's jelly protects the blood vessels in the umbilical cord. 

Structures seen in the histological section of the umbilical cord are shown in the below image.

questions.text: A first-year student while dissecting through the brachial plexus in a cadaver accidentally cut the structure marked “X”.  Had the same mistake been done by a surgeon in neck surgery, all of the following nerves would have been affected except:
questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'X' in the above image is the lateral cord, and hence all the nerves arising from it will be affected if the cord would have been cut by a surgeon during neck surgery. The thoracodorsal nerve arises from the posterior cord so its function can't be impaired due to an injury to the lateral cord.

The lateral cord is identified because the marked structure is formed from the superior and middle trunk only.

The lateral pectoral nerve and musculocutaneous nerve arise from the lateral cord.

The ulnar nerve is a branch of the medial cord however, it receives the lateral root of the median nerve originating from the lateral cord.

  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

questions.text: The structure marked in red gets its nerve supply from?
questions.solution:
The muscle shown in the image is piriformis and is supplied by branches from S1, S2.

 The piriformis muscle has its origin from the following structures.

  • The anterior surface of the sacrum
  • The posterior inferior iliac spine
  • The capsule of the sacroiliac joint
  • Sacrotuberous ligament

It is inserted into the greater trochanter of the femur. The muscle forms the posterolateral wall of the pelvic cavity. The sciatic nerve is closely related to the muscle and it passes through the muscle fibres or above the muscle.

Action: Lateral rotation of the thigh in extension and abduction of the thigh in the flexed position

Clinical note: Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle.

Other Options:

Superior gluteal nerve: Gluteus medius/minimus

The femoral nerve: Quadriceps femoris and many more.

The Sciatic nerve: Biceps femoris and many more

questions.text: Match the marked parts with their correct structures of the primitive heart tube.

choices.text: A-Bulbus cordis, B-Truncus arteriosus, C-Primitive ventricle, D-Sinus venosus
A-Truncus arteriosus, B-Bulbus cordis, C-Primitive atrium, D-Sinus venosus
A-Primitive atrium, B-Primitive ventricle, C-Bulbus cordis, D-Truncus arteriosus
A-Sinus venosus, B-Primitive atrium, C-Bulbus cordis, D-Truncus arteriosus

questions.solution:
The correct match is 

A-Sinus venosus

B-Primitive atrium

C-Bulbus cordis

D-Truncus arteriosus

The 2 heart tubes formed in the cardiogenic area fuse, except at their caudal most end, to become an inverted Y-shaped structure. During this fusion, the central part of the heart tube expands to form the future outflow tract and ventricular regions. The caudal pole of the tube receives the venous drainage, while the cranial end pumps out blood into the arterial system. 

The heart tube begins to bend by day 23. This bending creates the cardiac loop. The fate of various structures formed as a result of this bending is as follows:

 

Heart tube and their derivatives 
 Part of the heart tube Derivative structure in the heart

Bulbus cordis

  • Proximal 1/3 

 

  • Middle 1/3 (conus cordis)

 

  • Distal 1/3 (truncus arteriosus)

 

  • Trabeculated part of Right ventricle

 

  • Outflow tract of Right and Left ventricles

 

  • Root and proximal portions of aorta and pulmonary artery
Primitive ventricle
  • Trabeculated part of the Left ventricle
Primitive atrium
  • The common atrium that splits into Right and Left atrium

Development of the right atrium: It is formed from three main sources.

  • The right half of the primitive atrium
  • Absorption of the right half of AV canal
  • Absorption of the right horn of sinus venosus into the right half of the primitive atrium

Development of the left atrium: It is formed from three main sources.

  • The left half of the primitive atrial chamber
  • The left half of the AV canal
  • Absorbed proximal parts of the pulmonary veins

Development of the right and left ventricles:

  • The trabeculated part of the right ventricle is formed by the proximal third of the bulbus cordis. The trabeculated part of the left ventricle is formed by the primitive ventricle. 
  • The outflow parts such as the infundibulum of the right ventricle and aortic vestibule of the left ventricle are formed by the middle one-third of the bulbus cordis only, i.e. the conus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the structure marked with "?" in the image given below?

choices.text: Bartholin’s duct is the major duct
Lymphatic drainage is to the submental nodes
Obstruction of the duct causes ranula
It is seromucous but predominantly serous

questions.solution:
The structure marked "?" is the sublingual gland and it is seromucous but predominantly mucous.

The sublingual gland is the smallest of the main salivary glands. Small rami from the anterior part of the gland sometimes form a major sublingual duct (Bartholin’s duct), which opens with, or near to the orifice of the submandibular duct.

The sublingual gland is not removed in radical neck dissection.

If the ducts of any salivary gland become obstructed they can develop a retention cyst. If such cysts occur due to the obstruction in the sublingual salivary gland, it is called a ranula. A ranula usually presents as a large, tense, bluish swelling on the floor of the mouth to one side on the midline.

If the obstruction happens in the ducts of minor salivary glands such as labial or buccal, it is termed mucocele.

The clinical condition shown in the image given below is a ranula.

questions.text: A professor asks a student to identify the structure marked by the red arrows in the dissected part of the neck. He gives him a hint that this nerve arises from the medulla oblongata. He further adds that its damage causes the structure supplied by it to get deviated to the same side of the lesion. What is the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked with the red arrows in the image is the hypoglossal nerve. 

The hypoglossal nerve courses lateral to the internal and external carotid artery and the facial artery. The nerve then ascends along the lateral surface of the hyoglossus muscle.

The hypoglossal nerve supplies all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue, except the palatoglossus, which is supplied by the vago accessory nerve. Deviation of the tongue to the affected side is seen in injury to the hypoglossal nerve.

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: What is the basis for the formation of omphalocele?

choices.text: Physiological hernia failing to go back

questions.solution:
Omphalocele is protrusion of abdominal contents through the umbilical ring. It is due to failure of physiological hernia to reduce into the abdominal cavity, which results in non-closure of the umbilical ring. .

An omphalocele may contain stomach, liver, and intestines. And these contents are enclosed in a sac.

Omphalocele is usually associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of α-fetoprotein.

Note: In gastroschisis, there is an absence of a membranous sac and is paraumbilical.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

questions.text: The postmortem examination of an elderly man with chest pain showed a myocardial infarction in the area marked below. Occlusion of which of the following arteries is the cause of myocardial infarction in this patient?
questions.solution:
The area marked in the above image is the anterolateral wall of the left ventricle. This area is suppleid by the anterior interventricular artery which is likely to be occluded in this patient.

The left coronary artery arises from the left aortic sinus (left posterior sinus ) of the ascending aorta. It passes between the pulmonary trunk and the left auricle and then runs in the atrioventricular groove. 

It divides into two branches in the coronary sulcus. They are:

  • The anterior interventricular branch or left anterior descending artery (LAD) - Is the continuation of the left coronary artery. Gives anterior septal branches, anterior ventricular branches, and diagonal artery.
  • Circumflex branch (Options A)- Curves left in the atrioventricular groove and continues around the left cardiac border to reach the posterior part of the groove. It terminates in the crux in most hearts but may continue as a posterior interventricular artery in some individuals.

The left coronary artery supplies most of the left ventricle, a narrow strip of the right ventricle, the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum, and most of the left atrium.

The right coronary artery arises from the anterior aortic sinus. It first passes between the right atrium and the pulmonary trunk. On reaching the atrioventricular groove, it descends down vertically and curves around the right border of the heart to reach the inferior (posterior) part of the groove. The artery ends a little left of the cardiac crux by joining the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery. 

Branches of the right coronary artery are :

  • Right conal artery
  • Branches to the anterior part of the atrium and ventricles.
  • Right marginal artery (acute marginal artery) (Options C & D)
  • Posterior interventricular artery

The right coronary artery supplies most of the right ventricles, a small part of the diaphragmatic aspect of the left ventricle, the posteroinferior third of the interventricular septum, the right atrium and part of the left atrium, sinoatrial node, and atrioventricular node.

Dominance is determined by the vessel which supplies the posterior interventricular artery. If the posterior interventricular artery is derived from the left coronary artery it is called left dominance, if it is derived from the right coronary artery it is called right dominance.

questions.text: On neurologic examination, a patient is not able to recognize the key kept in his hand with his eyes closed. But, immediately recognizes the object once he sees it. Which lobe of the brain is likely affected in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of astereognosis. It is seen in lesions involving the superior parietal lobe which is marked as '3' in the given image.

Stereognosis is the ability to identify an object by a perception of the form and nature of an object without looking at it. This ability depends on intact touch, pressure, and proprioceptive impulses. The loss of integration of sensory impulses is called astereognosis. Astereognosis is seen in lesions of the superior parietal lobule and dorsal column pathways.

There are two parietal lobes, the dominant side, and the non-dominant side:

  • The functions of the dominant side of the parietal lobe are calculation, language, planned movement, appreciation of size, shape, weight, and texture. A lesion here causes dyscalculia, dysphasia, dyslexia, apraxia, agnosia, and homonymous hemianopia.
  • The function of the non-dominant side is spatial orientation and constructional skills. Its lesion causes spatial disorientation, constructional apraxia, neglect of the non-dominant side, dressing apraxia, and homonymous hemianopia.

The lesions in the posterior parietal lobe lead to loss of hand-eye coordination. Because neurons in this posterior parietal cortex contribute to the descending pathways involved in motor control.

Image below shows the marked area as 1,2,3 and 4

Related Pearl: CNS deficits and site of lesions

Term Defnition Site of lesion
Agnosia Inability to accurately perceive objects through normally functioning sensory mechanisms Posterior parietal cortex

Dyslexia

(word blindness)

Inability to interpret their meanings

(the person may be able to see words and even know that they are words but not be able to interpret their meanings)

Aphasia inability to produce and/or understand language

All components of the language network are interconnected with each other and with

surrounding parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. Damage

to this network gives rise to language impairments resulting in aphasia.

questions.text: A middle-aged man who presented with an abdominal mass has the following subcutaneous venous circulation with the direction of the flow as depicted by the arrows in the image. This can be seen in:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the upward flow of subcutaneous venous circulation can be seen in inferior vena cava obstruction.

The level of the umbilicus is a watershed area for venous and lymphatic circulation. The systemic veins anastomose with tributaries of portal veins at the umbilicus. Normally, venous blood and lymphatics flow upwards above the plane of the umbilicus and downwards below this plane. 

  • In inferior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal wall is completely upward.
  • In superior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal veins is completely downward.
  • In portal hypertension with dilated abdominal veins, the blood flow is away from the umbilicus, radiating like a star from the umbilicus (caput-medusae).

Causes of superior and inferior vena caval obstruction:

Causes of SVC obstruction Causes of IVC obstruction 

 

1. Mediastinal malignancy

2. Mediastinal fibrosis

3. Retrosternal thyroid

4. Aortic aneurysm

5. Radiation fibrosis

6. Iatrogenic
  1.  Thrombosis extension
  2.  Tumor invasion
  3.  Extrinsic compression (Eg: Pregnancy, abdominal mass)
  4. Coagulopathy
  5. Sepsis, dehydration, immobility
  6. Iatrogenic

Splenic vein thrombosis is one of the prehepatic causes of portal hypertension, in which the portal venous system is affected before it enters the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following cartilages form a complete ring?
questions.solution:
Cricoid cartilage forms a complete ring around the airway and this is the only laryngeal cartilage to do so.

Clinical significance:

  • Sellick's maneuver - Cricoid pressure is applied to occlude the esophagus without occluding the airway. It prevents regurgitation of gastric contents during intubation and rapid induction of anesthesia.
  • The cricoid cartilage is the narrowest part of the pediatric airway.

questions.text: An elderly female patient presented with sudden onset of dysphagia, dysarthria, vertigo, and abnormal gait. On examination, there is a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the face, right-sided horner's syndrome, and loss of pain and temperature on the left side of the body. Which of the following numbered vessels has most likely been thrombosed in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome or Wallenberg syndrome, which is seen in thrombosis of the PICA-posterior inferior cerebellar artery (marked as 12 in the above image).

The lateral part of the medulla is supplied by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery, a branch of the vertebral artery. Injury or thrombosis to this artery results in lateral medullary syndrome or Wallenberg syndrome leading to

  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature on the body- due to lateral spinothalamic tract
  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature on the face- due to spinal sensory nucleus of V nerve
  • Ataxia and intention tremors - due to spinocerebellar tract
  • Vertigo, nausea, vomiting, and nystagmus - due to vestibular nuclei
  • Dysphagia, dysarthria, and hoarseness of voice - due to nucleus ambiguous
  • Ipsilateral Horner syndrome-  due to sympathetic fibres

 The human brainstem blood supply and numbers in the above image denote:

  1. Anterior communicating artery
  2. Anterior cerebral artery
  3. Internal carotid artery
  4. Middle cerebral artery
  5. Posterior communicating artery
  6. Posterior cerebral artery
  7. Basilar artery
  8. Superior cerebellar artery
  9. Pontine arteries
  10. Vertebral artery
  11. Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  12. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  13. Anterior spinal artery

questions.text: A young man presents to the casualty after a stab injury to the back and the muscles marked below are injured. What is the prime action of these muscles?
questions.solution:
The muscles marked in the above image are rhomboids minor and major. These muscles cause retraction of the scapula.

Rhomboids minor and major are innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve. They are supplied by the dorsal scapular artery or the deep branch of the transverse cervical artery.

Muscles involved in movements of the scapula are:

  • Protraction (forward movement): Serratus anterior and pectoralis minor are prime movers. Rhomboid muscles control the rate and range of movements. The upper part of the latissimus dorsi acts like a strap across the inferior scapular angle in protraction.
  • Retraction (backward movement): Middle trapezius and rhomboids.
  • Elevation: Trapezius, Levator scapulae.
  • Depression: Usually gravity alone is sufficient for the depression of the scapula. When required, a part of the serratus anterior, pectoralis minor, and trapezius are used.

questions.text: An orthopaedician is performing the following test in a patient who has suffered a hyperextension injury to the right knee. He first places the patient in the supine position and the right leg is placed in slight external rotation. The knee is placed in a position between flexion and extension. He stabilises the femur with one hand and places the other hand in the posterior aspect of the tibia. He then gently pulls the tibia forwards. Which of the following structures is being tested in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
The test performed in the above scenario is the Lachman test. It is used to test the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). The structure marked as 3 in the above image is the anterior cruciate ligament.

Important tests that are performed to test the integrity of structures in the knee joint are:

  • Adduction (varus) stress test- Lateral (fibular) collateral ligament injuries.
  • Abduction stress test- Medial (tibial) collateral ligament injuries.
  • Anterior drawer test, Lachman test- Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Posterior drawer test, quadriceps active test- Posterior cruciate ligament
  • McMurray test, Apley grinding test, Thessaly test, squat test- menisci

The abnormal movement as shown in the image below gif that there is an injury to the ACL.

It is also called O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triad of the knee. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to a lateral blow to the knee.

It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

The image below shows the unhappy triad of the knee joint on MRI (PDW SPIR):

  1. Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
  2. Rupture of the medial collateral ligament
  3. Inner meniscal tear (image shows complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: A 39-year-old man, who is a chronic alcoholic, presented with complaints of abdominal distension, yellowish discoloration of eyes, and dark-colored urine for the past 6 months.  After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe and is scheduled for left hemi-hepatectomy. Which of the following segments has to be removed in the patient?

choices.text: II, III, IV, V, and VI

questions.solution:
In left hemi-hepatectomy (also called left hepatectomy), the segments marked as II, III, and IV should be removed. 

Cantlie’s line or main portal fissure extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava. It divides the liver into the right and left hemiliver. It contains the middle hepatic vein. The liver has 3 major fissures and 3 minor fissures.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage. Segment I corresponds to the liver's caudate lobe, and segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe of the liver. 

The Couinaud's liver segments are as follows:

Segments removed in various liver surgeries:

  • Right hepatectomy or right hemi-hepatectomy - V, VI, VII, VIII
  • Right tri-sectionectomy or extended right hepatectomy - IV, V, VI, VII, VIII
  • Left hepatectomy or left hemi-hepatectomy - II, III, and IV
  • Left tri-sectionectomy or extended left hepatectomy - II, III, IV, V, and VIII
  • Left lateral sectionectomy or bi-segmentectomy - II and III
  • Right posterior sectionectomy - VI, VII
  • Caudate lobectomy or segmentectomy - I

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Right Posterior sections

questions.text: Which of the following structures is related to the area marked as A in the given image below?
questions.solution:
The cadaveric image shown is of the left lung. The arch of aorta is related to the area marked as A in the given image. 

The left lung is divided into superior and inferior lobes by the oblique fissure. The pulmonary root connects the medial surface of the lung to the heart and trachea. It is formed by structures that enter or leave the hilum. The left root is present inferior to the arch of the aorta.

The vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum from above to below is:

  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal (hyparterial) bronchus, and
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

The arrangement of the lung hilar structures from the anterior to posterior in the order is:

  • Pulmonary vein
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Primary bronchus
  • Bronchial artery

The cadaveric image given below shows the structures related to the hilum of the left lung.

The cadaveric image given below shows the structures related to the hilum of the right lung.

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding nutrient artery?

choices.text: The vessels terminate in the periosteum
It supplies outer 1/3rd of the cortex
The nutrient foramen is directed away from the growing end

questions.solution:
The nutrient foramen is directed away from the growing end is the only true statement regarding nutrient artery. 

A nutrient artery enters the shaft through the nutrient foramen. It then runs through the cortex, and divides into ascending and descending branches in the medullary cavity. Each branch then divides into numerous small branches. These branches run parallel to the main artery and end in metaphysis by anastomosing with the epiphysial, metaphysial, and periosteal arteries.

The nutrient artery supplies the medullary cavity, inner two-thirds of the cortex, and metaphysis.

Nutrient foramen is directed away from the growing end of the bone. It can be remembered as "to the elbow I go and from the knee, I flee".

Blood supply of the Bone
Artery Regions supplied
Nutrient artery  Medullary cavity, inner 2/3 of the cortex, metaphysis
Metaphyseal arteries Metaphysis
Epiphyseal arteries Epiphysis and growth plate
Periosteal arteries Periosteum, outer 1/3 of the cortex

questions.text: The given cadaveric cross-section is at which vertebral level?
questions.solution:
The given cadaveric cross-section is at the level of the T-10 vertebra.

T-10 vertebral landmarks for the viscera: Lower border of lungs, cardia of stomach, liver, spleen, and sometimes, upper border of the kidney are seen. Inferior vena cava, azygos vein, and descending thoracic aorta can also be seen.

Other options:

Option A: At the level of T-4 lies concavity of aortic arch, azygos vein into SVC, bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk, upper border of the heart and tracheal bifurcation.

Option B: At the level of L-1 lies the pylorus, transpyloric plane, hilum of the left kidney, the origin of renal arteries and superior mesenteric artery, neck of the pancreas and termination of the spinal cord.

Option C: At the level of T-7 lies the inferior angle of the scapula, lower border of the heart & central tendon of the diaphragm.

questions.text: The sinus shown in the image opens into the ______.
questions.solution:
The structure shown in the image is the frontal sinus. It drains into the middle meatus.

The frontal sinus is the most superiorly located sinus. It is situated between the inner and outer tables of the frontal bone, above and deep to the supraorbital margin.

Paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present within the bones of the skull. These paranasal sinuses have been divided into two groups:

Anterior group:

  • Maxillary sinus (antrum of Highmore)
  • Frontal sinus
  • Anterior ethmoidal sinus

All of the above sinuses open in the middle meatus, and their ostia lie anterior to the basal lamella of the middle turbinate.

Posterior group:

  • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: Opens in the superior meatus 
  • Sphenoid sinus: Opens in sphenoethmoidal recess

Note: 

Maxillary and ethmoid sinuses (including both anterior and posterior ethmoidal sinuses) are present at birth. The frontal and the sphenoid sinuses are not present at birth.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Which among the following has been marked with the correct types of joints?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C.

1- Intervertebral joint- Secondary cartilaginous joint

2- Suture- Fibrous joint

3- Knee joint- Synovial joint

Structurally, joints are classified as fibrous joints, cartilaginous joints, and synovial joints. 

Structural classification of joints
Type  Subtypes
Fibrous joints
  • Sutures
  • Syndesmosis
  • Gomphosis
Cartilaginous joints
  • Primary cartilaginous (synchondrosis)
  • Secondary cartilaginous (symphysis)
Synovial joints
  • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
  • Sellar or saddle joints
  • Condylar or bicondylar joints
  • Ellipsoid joints
  • Hinge joints
  • Pivot or trochoid joints
  • Plane joints

 

The types of fibrous joints- sutures (a), syndesmosis (b), and gomphosis (c) are shown in the image below:

 

Types of cartilaginous joints:

  • Primary cartilaginous joint: The bones are united by a plate of hyaline cartilage, making the joint immovable. They are temporary joints because the cartilaginous plate gets replaced by bone. Examples are: 
    • The joint between epiphysis and diaphysis of a growing long bone
    • Spheno-occipital joint
    • First chondrosternal joint
    • Costochondral joints
  • Secondary cartilaginous joints: A thin layer of hyaline cartilage covers the articular surfaces, which are united by a fibrocartilaginous disc. These joints are permanent. Examples are :
    • Symphysis pubis
    • Manubriosternal joint
    • Intervertebral joints between the vertebral bodies

Primary (a) and secondary (b) cartilaginous joints are shown below.

 

The articular surfaces of synovial joints are covered with hyaline cartilage and are lubricated with synovial fluid. They are the most mobile joints. Types of synovial joints are shown in the image below: 

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: Which of the following is normally seen in lumbar spine?
questions.solution:
Lordosis is normally seen in lumbar spine.

In adults,

  • The cervical curve is a lordosis (convex forwards),
  • The thoracic curve is a kyphosis (convex dorsally),
  • The lumbar curve is also a lordosis,
  • The pelvic curve is concave anteroinferiorly.

questions.text: A histologist is studying the structure of lymphoid tissue. The below finding is seen in which of the following lymphoid tissues?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows Hassall's corpuscles; these are seen in the thymus. These are small rounded structures present in the medulla of the thymus. They have a central core of degenerated epithelial cells that stain pink. Around this is a circle of epithelial cells that stain pink with hematoxylin and eosin stains. The function of these corpuscles is not clearly understood.

Histology of thymus

The thymus is a lymphoid tissue that is arranged in the form of lobules. The lobules are separated from each other by connective tissue. 

Each lobule is made up of an outer darker staining cortex and an inner pale-staining medulla. The medulla contains pink rounded masses called Hassell's corpuscles.

Structure of a lymph node

Each lymph node is bean-shaped. The concave part consists of the hilum, through which the blood vessels enter and leave the node. Microscopy shows the following features:

Each lymph node is surrounded by a thin capsule. Below the capsule is the clear space, which is called the subcapsular sinus. 

The lymph node contains the outer cortex and an inner medulla. The cortex consists of densely packed lymphocytes and therefore stains dark. Numerous follicles can be seen in the cortex. Each nodule has a pale-staining germinal center surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. The medulla consists of lymphocytes arranged in the form of anastomosing cords. It appears pale. Numerous blood vessels can be seen in this area.

The image below shows the histology of the lymph node:

Structure of spleen (Option A)

The spleen is the largest lymphoid organ of the body.

Microscopic features of the spleen:

It is surrounded by a thick capsule. This capsule extends into the organ forming trabeculae. The substance of the spleen consists of red pulp and white pulp. In red pulp, the lymphocytes are diffusely distributed and contain numerous sinusoids. In white pulp, the lymphocytes are densely packed and arranged in the form of cords around the arterioles.

When cut transversely, the cords are similar to the nodules in the lymph nodes. They have a pale germinal center surrounded by a ring of densely packed lymphocytes. However, there is an eccentrically placed arteriole within the germinal center.

The image below shows the spleen: WP- white pulp, RP- Red pulp, CR- central arteriole.

Structure of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (Options B and C)

The aggregations are in the form of lymphatic follicles. Germinal centers may be present. Between the nodules, there is diffuse lymphoid tissue, which is called a parafollicular zone. The nodules predominantly consist of B lymphocytes with T lymphocytes in the diffuse areas.

They lie close to the epithelium. They are not surrounded by a capsule and also do not have connective tissue septa. They have a supporting network of reticular fibers. Examples are palatine tonsils, Peyer's patches, and lymphoid nodules in the vermiform appendix.

The image below shows Peyer's patches.

questions.text: A newborn infant is found to have a congenital urethral abnormality in which the urethral meatus opens on the ventral side of the penis. It is resulting in difficulty in directing the urine stream due to the ventral curvature of the penis. Which of the following is the cause of this malformation?

choices.text: Failure of the fusion of urethral folds

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes hypospadias. It occurs due to the incomplete fusion of the urethral folds.

Development of external genitalia in males

It is under the influence of androgens secreted by the fetal testes. The genital tubercle elongates to form phallus. During this elongation, the phallus pulls the urethral folds forward so that they form the lateral walls of the urethral groove. This groove extends along the ventral aspect of the elongated phallus, but not up to the glans. The urethral folds which form the lateral wall of the urethral groove fuse to form the penile urethra. The most distal part of urethra is formed by the penetration of the ectodermal cells from the tip of the glans. These form a short epithelial cord that forms the external urethral meatus.

Incomplete fusion of the urethral folds leads to hypospadiasis. 

Other options:

Option A- Splitting of genital tubercles leads to bifid or double penis.

Option C- Improper development of urorectal septum or cloaca leads to rectovaginal fistulas.

Option D- Improper developmental paramesonephric duct leads to uterine anomalies like uterus didelphys, uterus arcuatus, uterus bicornis, etc.
